course.name: Community and Cultural Identity

reviews.author: maksyu
reviews.title: Good for exploration
reviews.comment_content:
The course is a introduction to Anthropology. If you are interested in that, you will find this course is quite interesting since you will learn the research methods and many related concepts. Since there are no examinations, what you learn from class do not exert a great impact on your performance. Also, the reading materials are just for reference, you don't have to read them. To conclude, this course creates a "very free" learning atmosphere.

Instead of cramming you with tons of subject knowledge, this course encourages you to learn by exploring. You will be given 2 group research projects and 1 field trip report (individual) to do. The aim of the first project is to let you taste how to conduct a research like an anthropologist. Hence, we were assigned to conduct a research about one student society in HKUST, then do a presentation. After having the first taste, the difficulty of the second one is higher. You can freely choose a community in Hong Kong to study, then make a presentation and a group paper (12-15 pages in total, which is quite easy for a group of four students).
You are also required to attend at least one field trip organized by the （UST）South China Research Center, for example, Jiao Festival（太平清醮）.

Overall, this course is quite relaxing. It's even an enjoyment for those who love hands-on experience.

（By the way,  the majority of the students are international students（including exchange students）（I don't know whether it is coincidence）)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr.Qiu does not speak very fluent English, but it does not affect your understanding of the content. Also, she often looks at the computer or her notes while she is teaching （I guess that is because her spoken English is not very good, she just wants to make sure she does not speak anything wrong）. Hence, there are many students feel bored during classes.

However, she is definitely a sincere teacher. Although she won't create any quizzes for what she has taught, she still pays lots of effort on the course content （e.g. using various examples）.

Also, she does care students. Before the first tutorial, every student was asked to prepare a brief introduction of his or her cultural background. She memorized all! She often asks the cultural experience of some students base on their characteristics and background. For example, when we are talking about the life in student hall, she may "interview" students from foreign countries.  （This is quite nice). She is also quite acceptive. One of our students was not available to do the presentation, she allowed him to make a video. If you find it difficult to do your presentation on the designated date, you could talk to her and postpone your presentation （if no time clash）. Also, the deadline for submitting the final paper is quite late （the last day of examination）.  

Besides, the learning atmosphere she creates is quite relaxing. For example, there's a group providing snacks to the audience during the presentation. She's chilled with that.

In conclusion, she seems not very good at giving a lecture, but she is extremely nice,  considerate and supportive.

reviews.author: minna_
reviews.comment_content: This course introduces concepts on community and cultural identity mainly in the context of a Hong Kong village, called Yim Tin Tsai. Throughout the first half of the course, the professor mainly talks about different readings on topics such as the Kolb's Learning Cycle, cultural knowledge, world heritage and community revitalization. The second half of the course is mostly concentrated on the field trip and workshops at Yim Tin Tsai.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Cheung is passionate and knowledgeable about the course topic, therefore he tries to convey his comments as much as possible. However, his English is not very good, so foreign students might find it a little hard to understand the content. He also teaches relatively slowly, so expect time overrun in most of the lectures. One thing I really do not like about is that he always makes amendment to the course assignment (the learning portfolio) without making announcements, which makes it inflexible for students who already started doing the work.
He can memorize students' names and faces well, so if you do not attend a lecture, he will know that (and will send an email to you).
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is quite lax. If you attend most of the lectures and do your assignments seriously, you will at least get a B range.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite heavy. The learning portfolio constitutes the largest part of the grading. You have to write more than 10 reflections on readings and field trips, which I find very time-consuming. There are a total of 3 field trips to Yim Tin Tsai. The first time, students will attend both the salt production and Hakka teacake workshops. Students will choose either workshop and conduct the refined version. Students also have to make a handbook and a webpage on the workshop and the village.

The below grading is excerpted from the course syllabus:
Workshop Handbook 100
Workshop Presentation – Serving as a Docent 100
Learning Portfolio 150
A webpage for heritage workshop promotion 50
Peer Evaluation (1+2) 50
Total 450

reviews.author: tlmwty
reviews.comment_content:
This course is a critical introduction to the concept of communityfrom interdisciplinary perspectives.
• It explores the origins of the idea of community in Western utopian thought,
• the study of traditional and urban society in classical sociologyand anthropology,
•the enduring nostalgia for the idea of community as a source of security, belonging and identityin an increasingly insecure worldshaped by individualism, globalization, and the changing modes of communicationThe course explore case studiesof local multicultural communities in Hong Kong shaped by religion,lifestyles, ethnicity,nationalism,immigrationand emigration.
•It tackles China’s urbanism and its impacts on rural communitiesthrough migration of peasant worker, and also the impacts on urban communities through the development of gentrification and gated community.
•It also examine the Taiwan state program of community construction
FieldtripsandWork sheet will provide students with first-hand exposure and understanding of communal experiences through practices.
